Solve the system of equations: 

2x + 3y = 10 

4x - y = -7
message_2:
To solve this system of equations, we can use the substitution or elimination method. In this case, we will use the elimination method.

First, we want to make the coefficients of either x or y the same in both equations. We can do this by multiplying the first equation by 2:

(2x + 3y = 10) * 2
4x + 6y = 20

Now we have:
4x + 6y = 20
4x - y = -7

Next, we will subtract the second equation from the first equation to eliminate the x variable:

(4x + 6y) - (4x - y) = 20 - (-7)
4x + 6y - 4x + y = 27
7y = 27

Now, we can solve for y:

y = 27 / 7
y = 3

Now that we have the value of y, we can substitute it back into either of the original equations to solve for x. We will use the first equation:

2x + 3y = 10
2x + 3(3) = 10
2x + 9 = 10

Subtract 9 from both sides:

2x = 1

Now, divide by 2:

x = 1/2

So, the solution to the system of equations is x = 1/2 and y = 3.
